facts.text: Respondent instituted two suits against the appellant in the court of the First Civil Judge, Kanpur.

If the summons is not duly served,

holdings.text: We agree that the expression knowledge of the decree in art. 164 means knowledge of the particular decree which is sought to be set aside.

anchor.surface_text: We agree that the expression knowledge of the decree in art. 164 means knowledge of the particular decree which is sought to be set aside. When the summons was not duly served, limitation under art. 164 does not start running against the defendant because he has received some vague information that some decree has been passed against him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreeing with Davar J. in Pundlick Rowji case and followed by Calcutta and Bombay High Courts defining knowledge as specific to the decree challenged.

holdings.text: When the summons was not duly served, limitation under art. 164 does not start running against the defendant because he has received some vague information that some decree has been passed against him.

anchor.surface_text: When the summons was not duly served, limitation under art. 164 does not start running against the defendant because he has received some vague information that some decree has been passed against him. It is a question of fact in each case whether the information conveyed to the defendant is sufficient to impute to him knowledge of the decree within the meaning of art. 164.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Bombay HC in Bapurao Sitaram and others, rejecting start of limitation from mere vague notice.

holdings.text: It is a question of fact in each case whether the information conveyed to the defendant is sufficient to impute to him knowledge of the decree within the meaning of art. 164. The test of the sufficiency is not what the information would mean to a stranger, but what it meant to the defendant in the light of his previous dealings with the plaintiff and the facts and circumstances known to him.

anchor.surface_text: It is a question of fact in each case whether the information conveyed to the defendant is sufficient to impute to him knowledge of the decree within the meaning of art. 164. The test of the sufficiency is not what the information would mean to a stranger, but what it meant to the defendant in the light of his previous dealings with the plaintiff and the facts and circumstances known to him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contextual factual test based on defendant's position, derived from precedents emphasizing particularity over vagueness.

holdings.text: It is not necessary that a copy of the decree should be served on the defendant. It is sufficient that the defendant has knowledge of the material facts concerning the decree, so that he has a clear perception of the injury suffered by him and can take effective steps to set aside the decree.

anchor.surface_text: If from the information conveyed to him, the defendant has knowledge of the decree sought to be set aside, time begins to run against him under art. 164. It is not necessary that a copy of the decree should be served on the defendant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Extending interpretation of knowledge to material facts enabling action, consistent with Art. 164 purpose.

holdings.text: The appellant had thus on August 16, 1958 clear knowledge of the decree passed against him in suit No. 25 of 1958 which he now seeks to set aside. Time began to run against him from August 16, 1958 under art. 164 of the Indian Limitation Act, 1908.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had thus on August 16, 1958 clear knowledge of the decree passed against him in suit No. 25 of 1958 which he now seeks to set aside. Time began to run against him from August 16, 1958 under art. 164 of the Indian Limitation Act, 1908.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying sufficiency test to facts: presence in court, judge's direct information on connected decree, knowledge of mortgage dealings imputed specific knowledge.

holdings.text: The application filed by him on April 16, 1959 was, therefore, clearly barred by limitation and was rightly dismissed by the courts below.

anchor.surface_text: The application filed by him on April 16, 1959 was, therefore, clearly barred by limitation and was rightly dismissed by the courts below. In the result, the appeal is dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Over 30 days from knowledge date (Aug 16, 1958) to filing (Apr 16, 1959), confirming lower courts under Art. 164.

holdings.text: Under O.9 r.13 CPC, where summons not duly served, defendant entitled ex debito justitiae to set aside ex-parte decree if within limitation.

If the summons is not duly served,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Standard application of CPC provision, accepted summons not served but limitation fatal.

precedents.citation: Pundlick Rowji v. Vasant rao Madhavrao 1

anchor.surface_text: Pundlick Rowji v. Vasant rao Madhavrao 1 , Davar, J., held that the expression knowledge of the decree in art 164 means knowledge number of a decree but of the particular decree which is sought to be set aside, a certain and clear perception of the fact that the particular decree had been passed against him. On the facts of that case, Davar, J., held that a numberice to the defendant that a decree had been passed against him in the High Court Suit No. 41 1 of 1909 in favour of one Pundlick Rowji with whom he had numberdealings was number sufficient to impute to him clear knowledge of the decree in the absence of any information that the decree had been passed in favour of pundlick Rowji as the assignee of a promissory numbere which he had executed in favour, of another party.

precedents.case_name: Pundlick Rowji v. Vasant Rao Madhavrao
precedents.cited_proposition: the expression knowledge of the decree in art 164 means knowledge number of a decree but of the particular decree which is sought to be set aside, a certain and clear perception of the fact that the particular decree had been passed against him
precedents.cited_holding: a numberice to the defendant that a decree had been passed against him in the High Court Suit No. 41 1 of 1909 in favour of one Pundlick Rowji with whom he had numberdealings was number sufficient to impute to him clear knowledge of the decree in the absence of any information that the decree had been passed in favour of pundlick Rowji as the assignee of a promissory numbere which he had executed in favour of another party

precedents.citation: Kumud Nath Roy Chowdhury v. Jotindra Nath Chowdhury 1

anchor.surface_text: This case was followed by the Calcutta High Court in Kumud Nath Roy Chowdhury v. Jotindra Nath Chowdhury 1 . , In Bapurao Sitaram Karmarkar v. Sadbu Bhiva, Gholap 3 , the Bombay High Court held that the evidence of two, persons who had been asked by the plaintiff to. tell the defendant about the decree and to settle the matter was number sufficient to impose knowledge of the decree on the defendant within the meaning of art. 164.

precedents.case_name: Kumud Nath Roy Chowdhury v. Jotindra Nath Chowdhury
precedents.cited_proposition: followed the case of Pundlick Rowji v. Vasant rao Madhavrao on the meaning of knowledge of the decree under art. 164

precedents.citation: Bapurao Sitaram Karmarkar v. Sadbu Bhiva, Gholap 3

anchor.surface_text: In Bapurao Sitaram Karmarkar v. Sadbu Bhiva, Gholap 3 , the Bombay High Court held that the evidence of two, persons who had been asked by the plaintiff to. tell the defendant about the decree and to settle the matter was number sufficient to impose knowledge of the decree on the defendant within the meaning of art. 164. Macleod J. said We think. the words of the article mean something more than mere knowledge that a decree had been passed in some suit in some Court against the applicant.

precedents.case_name: Bapurao Sitaram Karmarkar v. Sadbu Bhiva Gholap
precedents.cited_proposition: evidence of two persons asked by plaintiff to tell defendant about the decree not sufficient to impose knowledge of the decree under art. 164; requires knowledge of particular decree in particular court for particular person for particular sum
precedents.cited_holding: We think. the words of the article mean something more than mere knowledge that a decree had been passed in some suit in some Court against the applicant. We think it means that the applicant must have knowledge number merely that a decree has been passed by some Court against, him, but that a particular decree has been passed against him in a particular Court in favour of a particular person for a particular sum.

anchor.surface_text: This decision was followed in Batulan v. S. K. Dwivedi 1  and other cases. We agree that the expression knowledge of the decree in art. 164 means knowledge of the particular decree which is sought to be set aside. When the summons was number duly served, limitation under art. 164 does number start running against the defendant because he has received some vague information that some decree has been passed against him.

precedents.cited_proposition: followed the decision in Bapurao Sitaram Karmarkar v. Sadbu Bhiva Gholap on the meaning of knowledge of the decree under art. 164

anchor.surface_text: It is a question of fact in each case whether the information conveyed to the defendant is sufficient to impute to him knowledge of the decree within the meaning of art. 164. The test of the sufficiency is not what the information would mean to a stranger, but what it meant to the defendant in the light of his previous dealings with the plaintiff and the facts and circumstances known to him.
In the result, the appeal is dismissed with companyts.
